doc.title: Foshan Haitian Flavouring & Food Co Ltd (A)
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Foshan Haitian Flavouring Food Co Ltd A Core businesses remain healthy reiterate Neutral on fair valuationFoshan Haitian_2025-08-29

passages.text: Reiterate Rating: NEUTRAL | PO: 43.00 CNY | Price: 40.08 CNY

Result in line; weak restaurant channels cast cloudHaitian's sales/NPAT were \(+7.6\% / + 11.6\%\) in 2Q25, vs. \(+8.1\% / + 14.8\%\) in 1Q, in line with market expectations. Core businesses maintained healthy growth (sales \(+10.6\%\) YoY in 2Q, vs. \(+10.3\%\) in 1Q) but the decline in other sales (- 35% YoY in 2Q) was a key drag. With the new management team on board and the further implementation of channel reform, Haitian enjoyed solid growth across the board with c. \(10\%\) sales growth for most core products and regions in 2Q. Looking into 2H, we expect this trend could sustain thanks to 1) a broad and balanced domestic footprint with increased penetration in lower tier cities and presence in emerging channels (online sales \(+38\%\) YoY in 1H), 2) product and package innovation catering to evolving consumer preference, and 3) continued efforts in category expansions, such as in flavored sauce and compound condiment. However, the slower recovery in food services channels (esp. after China's ban in official dining), which may lead to the need of destocking or more margin reinvestments (to drive sell- through), remains our key concern. We cut our above- consensus 2025/26 EPS \(4\% /3\%\) on lower sales estimates, and our PO \(5\%\) to RMB43.0. The stock trades at \(>30x\) 2025E P/E and thus we believe the near- term positives have been mostly priced in. Moreover, Haitian's H- share trades at a \(22\%\) discount on its A- share, which may cap the A- share valuation re- rating, in our view. We reiterate our Neutral rating.

1H/2Q25 results highlights1H25 revenue/NPAT was \(+7.6\% / + 13.3\%\) YoY. Revenue was \(+7.0\%\) YoY in 2Q25, vs \(+8.1\%\) in 1Q25. Sales of soy sauce/soy sauce/seasoning paste/others (53.3%/7.4%/10.8%/18.5% of total in 2Q25) were \(+10.3\% / + 9.8\% / + 9.6\% / + 12.7\%\) YoY. By region, sales in Northern/Central/Southern/Eastern/Western (25.3%/21.6%/22.1%/25.3%/12.5% of total) were \(+10.8\% / + 10.5\% / + 11.3\% / + 12.8\% / + 6.0\%\) YoY. GPM was \(+38b\) p to 40.2% in 2Q, thanks to raw- materials cost deflation and production efficiency improvement. S&D/sales was \(+35\) bp to 7.0%, as Haitian increased spending in 2Q to facilitate faster sell- out. and G&A/sales was \(+40\) bp to 5.5%. Net- net, 2Q OP was \(+20.2\%\) YoY with OPM \(+295\) bp to 26.8%. With effective tax rate of 15.8% in 2Q25 (vs 15.0% in 2Q24), NPAT was \(+11.6\%\) YoY in 2Q (vs. \(+14.8\%\) in 1Q), with NPM \(+101\) bp to 24.8%.
\\* For full definitions of Qmethod means, see page 7.

Key Metrics \\* For full definitions of iQmethod measures, see page 7.

Foshan Haitian Flavoring and Food Company was founded in 1955. It went through two rounds of shareholding reforms and became a privately-held company in 2007 jointly controlled by employees. Its major products include soy sauce, oyster sauce and seasoning paste. Haitian enjoys the largest volume share in both soy sauce and oyster sauce. The company was listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in January 2014.

We have a Neutral rating on Haitian. We recognize Haitian as a high- quality condiment company with strong brand equity and established distribution. Its market share regains, diversifying portfolio, and gradual demand recovery could support its path to growth re- acceleration. We also believe Haitian's profitability is well on track to recover. However, this is tempered by its fair valuation and we see risks related to its HK listing plans.
Exhibit 1: Haitian: Earnings revision
We cut 2025/26E EPS 4%/3%
Source: Company, BofA Global Research estimates
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

We cut our 2025/26E EPS 4%/3% post the results to reflect lower sales estimates and our PO 5% from RMB45.5 to RMB43.0, based on a 50/50 blend of P/E and DCF valuation. Our P/E-based valuation is RMB40.5, based on unchanged 32x 2025E P/E. Our DCF-derived valuation is RMB45.5, based on 8.0% WACC, 0.66x beta, and 3% terminal growth (unchanged).
Exhibit 2: Haitian: Result at a glance
Haitian's revenue/NPAT were +7.0%/+11.6% in 2Q25

BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

We derive our RMB43.0/share PO from a 50/50 blend of P/E (RMB40.5) and DCF (RMB45.5). Our P/E valuation is based on 32x 2025E P/E, largely in line with leading A- share consumer staple companies. Our DCF valuation is based on 8% WACC, 0.66x beta, and 3% terminal growth.

Downside risks: macro weakness, food safety issues, raw material price fluctuation, execution risks in channel expansion, delays in mix upgrade/product innovation, rising competition, and key personnel risk. Upside risks: strong restaurant demand recovery, rapid acquisition of new 2B clients, solid market share gain.
